misconceptions.name: Reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for three values (v0, v1, t) as doubles rather than reading five separate integers as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should read three numeric inputs (v0, v1, t) as doubles for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read exactly five integers from the user, not three doubles, in order to compute the sum of the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Prompt asks for three named values instead of five integers.
Only three numbers are read from input.
Input type is double instead of int.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about the problem requirements or reuse of an unrelated example that reads three doubles.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input section to read five int values (e.g., in a loop) instead of three doubles, and store each as an int.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt string and three consecutive nextDouble() calls clearly show that only three doubles are read instead of five integers.

evidence.note: Reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop to handle multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program does not use any loop to process multiple inputs; it makes a fixed number of input calls instead of iterating over five values.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is sufficient to call nextDouble() a fixed number of times without using a loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To handle five integers in a scalable and clear way, the program should use a loop to read and process each of the five inputs.
symptoms: No for or while loop in the program.
Inputs are read using three explicit nextDouble() calls.
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of application of loop constructs to handle repeated input operations.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for-loop or while-loop that iterates five times, reading one integer each time and updating the running sum as appropriate.
related_concepts: Iterating over a fixed number of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire main method has no looping construct and uses only direct input calls.

evidence.note: Main method uses direct input calls with no loop to handle multiple values.

misconceptions.name: No conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (e.g., using n % 2 == 0) and therefore cannot selectively sum only even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The task does not require distinguishing even from odd numbers, or the student overlooked the need for a modulo-based check.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only even numbers, each input should be tested with a condition such as if (n % 2 == 0) before adding it to the sum.
symptoms: No use of the modulo operator %
No conditional statements related to even/odd checking
Program computes a physics formula instead of conditionally summing inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to incorporate conditional logic for filtering even numbers, possibly due to focusing on an unrelated example.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add an if statement inside the input-processing loop that checks if the current integer is even with n % 2 == 0 before adding it to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no conditional or modulo usage anywhere in the code, and the logic is unrelated to filtering numbers.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Performs a single arithmetic computation and prints it; no conditionals or modulo checks for even numbers appear in the program.
